fields.value: Replication data for to Developing and implementing the Global Trigger Tool methodology across a large health system in Sicily

authorAffiliation.value: U.O. Quality management and patients safety - Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Catania, Italy

datasetContactAffiliation.value: U.O. Quality management and patients safety - Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Catania, Italy

dsDescriptionValue.value: Even though several methods to detect AEs are available, there is no universally recognized method that reliably provides a comprehensive overview of the extent of the problem.  IHI proposed a new methodology, the Global Trigger Tool ( IHI GTT), to detect and monitor adverse events and provide information to implement improvement. In 2015, the Sicilian Health System (SHS) adopted IHI GTT to assess the number, types, and severity levels of adverse events in 2015. To perform this reliably and uniformly, a centralized process was developed. The GTT was implemented in 44 of the 73 Sicilian public hospitals. 18,008 clinical records were examined. In this paper, we present the standardized application of the GTT and the preliminary results of 14,706 reviews of clinical records in medicine, surgery, obstetric and ICU wards, evaluated from June 2015 to June 2018.

files.description:
The data are referred to clinical records in which were found one or more triggers.
The clinical records without triggers were not included.
The first column contains the identification number assigned to the clinical record by the review team.
In the column B is indicated the numeric identification code of the Hospitals that were involved in the study.
In the column C is indicated the alphanumeric identification code of the hospitals wards that were involved in the study.
In the column D is indicated the clinical area of the hospitals wards that were involved in the study.
ICU = Intensive Care Unit
In the column E is indicated the month in which the clinical record was reviewed.
In the column F is indicated the year in which the clinical record was reviewed.
In the columns from G to BD is reported the presence of triggers in the clinical records. 
The number 1 indicates the presence of a trigger in the corresponding column.
The value in the BE column indicates the number of Adverse Events found in the single clinical record.
files.label: Clinical records with triggers 1.0.xlsx

dataFile.description:
The data are referred to clinical records in which were found one or more triggers.
The clinical records without triggers were not included.
The first column contains the identification number assigned to the clinical record by the review team.
In the column B is indicated the numeric identification code of the Hospitals that were involved in the study.
In the column C is indicated the alphanumeric identification code of the hospitals wards that were involved in the study.
In the column D is indicated the clinical area of the hospitals wards that were involved in the study.
ICU = Intensive Care Unit
In the column E is indicated the month in which the clinical record was reviewed.
In the column F is indicated the year in which the clinical record was reviewed.
In the columns from G to BD is reported the presence of triggers in the clinical records. 
The number 1 indicates the presence of a trigger in the corresponding column.
The value in the BE column indicates the number of Adverse Events found in the single clinical record.

files.description:
The data are referred to clinical records in which were found one or more adverse events.
The clinical records without adverse events were not included.
The first column contains the identification number assigned to the clinical record by the review team.
In the column B is indicated the numeric identification code of the Hospitals that were involved in the study.
In the column C is indicated the alphanumeric identification code of the hospitals wards that were involved in the study.
In the column D is indicated the clinical area of the hospitals wards that were involved in the study.
ICU = Intensive Care Unit
In the column E is indicated the month in which the clinical record was reviewed.
In the column F is indicated the year in which the clinical record was reviewed.
In the column BE are provided the descriptions of the adverse events according to the clinical classification used by our team.
In the column BF are provided the descriptions of the adverse events according to the International Classification for Patient Safety (ICPS) – WHO 2009.
In the columns from G to BD is reported the presence of triggers in the clinical records in which was found an adverse event. The number 1 indicates the presence of a trigger in the corresponding column.
In 7 adverse events found in 7 different clinical records were not been found positive triggers. In those cases the triggers were not searched because the adverse events were early detected.
files.label: Clinical records with triggers&adverse events 1.0.xlsx

dataFile.description:
The data are referred to clinical records in which were found one or more adverse events.
The clinical records without adverse events were not included.
The first column contains the identification number assigned to the clinical record by the review team.
In the column B is indicated the numeric identification code of the Hospitals that were involved in the study.
In the column C is indicated the alphanumeric identification code of the hospitals wards that were involved in the study.

In the column BE are provided the descriptions of the adverse events according to the clinical classification used by our team.
In the column BF are provided the descriptions of the adverse events according to the International Classification for Patient Safety (ICPS) – WHO 2009.
In the columns from G to BD is reported the presence of triggers in the clinical records in which was found an adverse event. The number 1 indicates the presence of a trigger in the corresponding column.
In 7 adverse events found in 7 different clinical records were not been found positive triggers. In those cases the triggers were not searched because the adverse events were early detected.
